list.text: Interventions have 3 parameters: type of intervention, side of intervention and desired final price

Types of intervention and relevant parameters: 1. No intervention 2. Tax  3. Subsidy 4. Price floor 5. Price support  6. Production quota 7. Voluntary reduction (use the purple button on the left to change this)
Tax and subsidy can be either on producer (side=1) or consumer (side=2) side and can both reduce or increase the price (use the red button on the left to change this)
Policies 4-7 are relevant only for price increase
Move price slider (and optional tax or subsidy sliders) o adjust desired final price
Miller & Tashevtev "Desmos Graphs for Micro"
Designed by: Joshua B. Miller, Department of Economics, University of Melbourne, joshua.benjamin.miller@gmail.com, https://www.joshua-benjamin-miller.com/
Desmos commands by Artem Tashevtev & Joshua Miller
This folder defines demand and supply curves and calculates the equilibrium price and quantity
An alternative way to calculate areas - use numerical integration
Define choice for type of intervention (i.e. tax or price floor)
Define choice for side of intervention (producers or consumers)

2 equations below define minimum and maximum possible prices for different combinations of parameters. For all interventions but subsidy and tax price can vary from P_eq to maximal. For tax and subsidy,  there are limits of type: "tax on producers can only raise price" and so on
Define P_min and P_max as minimum and maximum price achievable with current intervention
Add slider to change the desired price
Quantity supplied and demanded at desired price P1:

Calculating subsidy/taxes on producers/consumers + define draggable points.  Subsidy on producers is denoted as S_p, Tax on Consumers is denoted T_c and so on. For producers, tax/subsidy is calculated as the difference between P1 and Inverse Supply at Quantity demanded. For consumers, tax/subsidy is calculated as the difference between P1 and Inverse Demand at Quantity supplied
Horizontal line at P1
Click legend for different welfare effects
For each intervention, first define a list of points which form the welfare polygon and then display it
Effect of tax and subsidy on producer can be seen as shift of supply curve in either direction
New supply curve:
Arrow representing tax/subsidy:
Define CS and PS as area between respective curves, and DWL and Revenue as polygons:
Effect of tax and subsidy on consumer can be seen as shift of demand curve in either direction
New demand curve:
On Consumer side, subsidy may be too large - it happens when subsidy is large enough to make price paid by consumers negative
On Consumer side, tax may be too large - it happens when tax is large enough to make price received by producers less than Inverse Supply at 0
Arrow representing tax/subsidy:
Define CS and PS as area between respective curves, and DWL and Revenue as polygons:
